title: Kolaramma
text:
Kolaramma is the presiding <a href="deity">deity</a> of the town of <a href="Kolar">Kolar</a> in <a href="Karnataka">Karnataka</a>,<a href="India">India</a>. The Kolaramma temple is thousand years old and built by the <a href="Chola%20Rulers">Cholas</a> in the South Indian style. Goddess <a href="Parvathi">Parvathi</a> is worshipped as Kolaramma by the people of Kolar. The erstwhile maharajas of <a href="Mysore">Mysore</a> frequently visited this temple to get the blessings of Kolaramma. The temple itself has beautifully carved statues and designs all done using the abundantly available <a href="granite">granite</a> stones.
Another deity of this temple is <a href="Chelamma">Chelamma</a> or the <a href="Scorpion%20goddess%20%28disambiguation%29">scorpion goddess</a>. People believe that by praying at the Chelamma shrine a person will be guarded from <a href="scorpion">scorpion</a> bites by the deity.
Another interesting thing about the temple is the <a href="Hundi%20%28cash%20collection%20box%29">hundi</a> or the well which is used to collect money offerings from the people, and it is a tradition to at least put one coin into the small opening on the floor of the temple, which apparently is a large hole dug into the earth, one can still hear the clicking sounds of coins accumulated over hundreds of years.
